Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI: Testing Resolution of Deep Earth Seismic Structure Under the Pacific Using Geodynamic Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
The temperature and composition structure in the Earth's lower mantle provides important clues to the chemical differentiation and dynamics of the planet, especially in regard to how heat is transported from the core to the mantle. A large-scale, slow seismic-velocity anomaly in the lower mantle beneath the Pacific has been imaged in tomographic studies. The thermal and compositional structure of this anomaly remains poorly understood. This research integrates seismological and geodynamical efforts to investigate important issues in understanding the structure of this deep seismic anomaly. We will use thermochemical convection models to develop candidate mantle structures that can be investigated with seismic wave propagation simulations using realistic earthquake and receiver geometries. This will allow us to identify seismic phases that are sensitive to differences between the candidate mantle structures and to investigate whether finite-frequency theory provides additional insight beyond ray-theory for the geometry of these structures, and how 3-D attenuation structure affects our interpretation of tomographic images.

This research addresses several challenging problems in understanding the thermal and chemical structure in the Pacific lower mantle through seismic wave propagation in thermo-chemical plume models with focuses on (1) the sensitivity of seismic waves to 3-D variations in temperature and compositional in the lower mantle; (2) the effects of different scaling parameters in translation between temperature and compositional anomalies to seismic wave speed and anelastic attenuation and (3) the resolution limits of current seismic data (including USArray data) and seismic tomographic methods (ray theory and finite-frequency theory) in imaging the structure of the Pacific lower mantle and distinguishing between different plume models including 1) the 'standard' isochemical whole mantle model, with a cluster of narrow plumes under the central Pacific, 2) a thermochemical 'dome' (or pile) under the central Pacific with plumes arising from the interface, and 3) an isolated, sluggish lower mantle with upper mantle derived plumes. Seismological challenges, including quantifying the relative importance of anelastic attenuation and focusing-defocusing effects, and tradeoffs between elastic and anelastic structure will be addressed with full wave propagation simulations in a variety of thermochemical plume models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The southern Pacific Ocean is characterized by a large number of volcanic islands and anomalously shallow seafloor. This region is known to Earth Scientists are the superswell. There are several proposed explanations for the excess volcanism and shallow sea floor including a 1000-km wide column of anomalously hot rock (i.e., a superplume) or a number of narrower (100-km wide) structures spaced beneath the major volcanic centers. The work in this proposal addressed this region with a two-fold approach: improving the method by which seismologists image the structure beneath this volcanic zone and using high-performance computing simulations to model the shallow topography in this region.

 

Seismic waves generated by natural earthquakes travel through the deep interior of the Earth before returning to the surface of the Earth. By studying seismic waves (ground motions) recorded at seismometers deployed at the surface of the Earth, seismologists can image physical properties of the Earth's interior. In the past decades, the theory has been based on an approximation, therefore, seismologists were only able to obtain a blurred image of the Earth's interior. We improved seismic method to uses more of the signal from an earthquake than previously used by seismologists. Advanced mathematical and computational theory was necessary in order to use this additional information and this required advanced supercomputers with much more computational ability than what was available even a few years ago. One result of this improved theory is that the suggestion that a change in composition deep within the Earth gives rise to the single large structure is not required. To understand the anomalously shallow ocean floor we undertook a global study of the ocean floor. We developed simulations of flow within the planet based on principles of buoyancy, where regions of the interior that are hotter than average lead to rising material and regions that are colder than average lead to sinking flow. We were able to show that areas that are anomalously shallow correspond to regions where our numerical simulations find rising material pushes the surface upward and regions of the ocean floor that are anomalously deep correspond to regions of our simulations where material is sinking deep within the Earth.

 

 

The results have been published in research papers, student thesis and conference presentations. The new findings have been incorporated in teaching materials in undergraduate and graduate courses taught at Virginia Tech. This grant provided training opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students and a postdoc.
